awd_titl_txt: Particle Physics at the Energy Frontier with the CMS Experiment
awd_abstract_narration:
This program of research aims to better understand the Universe at the smallest scales by probing nature's basic symmetries and their relation to the origin of mass. The 2012 discovery of a Higgs boson with mass close to 125 GeV represents both the crowning achievement of the standard model of particle physics and a hint beyond it - how can a light Higgs boson possibly survive huge, destabilizing quantum effects without new, undiscovered physics? Further, dark matter is known to exist from astronomical observations; however, the particle properties of dark matter remain shrouded in mystery. The combined activities of the University of Kansas (KU) group address such basic questions puzzling physics - the origin of mass and the particle nature of dark matter - and have the potential for surprising discoveries that may change the way we understand our physical world. 

This award will provide support for the KU group's work on the CMS experiment at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN, a particle physics laboratory in Geneva, Switzerland.  Analytically, the group has a broad range of physics interests, including searches for vector-like quarks and the initiation into new searches for evidence of supersymmetry, with emphasis on signatures that emphasize compressed spectra and "ewino" cascades.

Technically, KU will continue to work with the CMS tracker system, both to support the current operations and to develop new components for the future high luminosity HL-LHC era.  KU will design, test and build cables that will bring the high-speed electronic signals from the HL-LHC inner pixel tracker modules to optical links on the detector and assess how the full chain of electronic readout performs.   This pixel tracker system is critical to the reconstruction of many event types of special interest to the CMS program of discovery science. 

The group has two major continuing outreach efforts: a long-standing QuarkNet center, through which it engages with area high school physics teachers and their students, and the multimedia Quarked! project that presents modern physics concepts to youth through games, videos, and other web content.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The principal discipline of this NSF project is experimental elementary particle physics. The Standard Model is a very successful theory that describes the fundamental particles and the forces through which they interact. The University of Kansas (KU) experimental particle physics group makes its impact on the field primarily through its efforts with the CMS experiment. The CMS experiment is one of two general purpose experiments operating at CERN’s Large Hadron Collider (LHC). CMS makes a wide variety of important measurements, exploring Standard Model phenomena and searching for phenomena beyond the Standard Model. The LHC is presently the world’s premier collider, colliding protons at an unprecedented energy of 13.6 TeV. Run I of the LHC featured collisions at center-of-mass energies of 7 and 8 TeV. Run II of the LHC provided a substantially larger data sample at a center-of-mass energy of 13 TeV. Run III of the accelerator started in 2022, should considerably expand the total size of the data set, and explores a slightly higher energy, 13.6 TeV. During the period of this funding the LHC was shut down between Runs II and III. Important goals for this grant period included analysis of the Run II data set, analyzing the performance of the detector, and developing future detectors for the high luminosity LHC (HL-LHC) and the international linear collider (ILC). The HL-LHC, planned to operate beginning in 2026, would increase the amount of proton collision data by about a factor of ten. The ILC would provide complementary physics from electron-positron collisions.

Most of the funding from the NSF went into salary support for researchers. The three faculty investigators, Philip Baringer, Alice Bean and Graham Wilson, work with CMS as their primary or sole research focus. The grant also funded two postdoctoral researchers, Anna Kropivnitskaya and Sadia Khalil. Three graduate students were supported, one of whom completed his Ph.D. during this funding period. Several undergraduate students were also provided research experiences from this grant.

Even though the Standard Model is very successful, there are many important questions that this model leaves unanswered. Thus, the Kansas group is looking for phenomena beyond the standard model, exploring hypothetical new particles known as vector-like top quark partners, stop squarks, and electroweakinos. In the first year of the funding the KU group wrapped up its search for a vector-like quark that decays into a top quark and a Higgs boson. No evidence was found for such an object and a journal article was published to report this negative finding. The group continues to investigate supersymmetric particle production (stops and electroweakinos). Supersymmetry (SUSY) is one of the best motivated models for new physics and KU is using new techniques and new channels to gain sensitivity to previously neglected experimental signatures.

Kansas has also made substantial contributions to the development and operation of the CMS detector. We were part of the efforts to operate the pixel detector that was installed in early 2017, as well as the silicon strip tracker and its associated online and offline software. These detectors use solid-state components, somewhat similar to the technology in a digital camera, to track the paths of particles that emerge from the proton collisions. KU’s CMS detector performance work centers on the tracker system, and we used novel techniques to map material in the inner detector using the 2015 and 2018 data. Anna Kropivnitskaya served and presently Graham Wilson serves as convener of the CMS tracker subgroup that studies material.

Development of future detectors is another important goal for the group. KU is designing, testing and building cables that will bring the high-speed electronic signals from the HL-LHC inner tracker modules to optical links on the detector and assess how the full chain of electronic readout performs. Wilson is active in preparing for a future high energy electron-positron collider, including overseeing and steering the efforts of an ILC detector concept group and convening a working group on Higgs and electroweak physics.

The KU group also has two major continuing outreach efforts: a long-standing QuarkNet center, through which it engages with area high school physics teachers and their students, and the multimedia Quarked! project (www.quarked.org) that presents modern physics concepts to youth through games, videos, and other web content.

The group’s broader educational mission also includes communicating about science with the general public through public talks and other means. Particle physics explores questions about nature at its most basic level. We can see in our public lectures that there is great curiosity about these questions. Through our outreach work, group members have interacted with various segments of our community, and there is always common ground for meaningful conversations. We hope to inspire interest in and respect for science as a way of exploring deep issues.
